title: The Misguided War on the SAT
text:
'Picking Up Fundamentals'

A Fixed Benchmark

The View From MIT

A Question of Values

This article originally appeared in The New York Times.

After the COVID pandemic made it difficult for high school students to take the SAT and ACT, dozens of selective colleges dropped their requirement that applicants do so. Colleges described the move as temporary, but nearly all have since stuck to a test-optional policy . It reflects a backlash against standardized tests that began long before the pandemic, and many people have hailed the change as a victory for equity in higher education .Now, though, a growing number of experts and university administrators wonder whether the switch has been a mistake. Research has increasingly shown that standardized test scores contain real information, helping to predict college grades , chances of graduation and post-college success. Test scores are more reliable than high school grades, partly because of grade inflation in recent years.Without test scores, admissions officers sometimes have a hard time distinguishing between applicants who are likely to do well at elite colleges and those who are likely to struggle. Researchers who have studied the issue say that test scores can be particularly helpful in identifying lower-income students and underrepresented minorities who will thrive. These students do not score as high on average as students from affluent communities or white and Asian students. But a solid score for a student from a less privileged background is often a sign of enormous potential."Standardized test scores are a much better predictor of academic success than high school grades," Christina Paxson, the president of Brown University , recently wrote. Stuart Schmill -- the dean of admissions at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, one of the few schools to have reinstated its test requirement -- said, "Just getting straight A's is not enough information for us to know whether the students are going to succeed or not."An academic study released in the summer by the group Opportunity Insights, covering the so-called Ivy Plus colleges (the eight in the Ivy League, along with Duke, MIT, Stanford and the University of Chicago), showed little relationship between high school grade-point average and success in college. The researchers found a strong relationship between test scores and later success.Likewise, a faculty committee at the University of California system -- led by Dr. Henry Sánchez, a pathologist, and Eddie Comeaux, a professor of education -- concluded in 2020 that test scores were better than high school grades at predicting student success in the system's nine colleges, where more than 230,000 undergraduates are enrolled. The relative advantage of test scores has grown over time, the committee found."Test scores have vastly more predictive power than is commonly understood in the popular debate," said John Friedman, an economics professor at Brown and one of the authors of the Ivy Plus admissions study.With the Supreme Court's restriction of affirmative action last year, emotions around college admissions are running high. The debate over standardized testing has become caught up in deeper questions about inequality in America and what purpose, ultimately, the nation's universities should serve.But the data suggests that testing critics have drawn the wrong battle lines. If test scores are used as one factor among others -- and if colleges give applicants credit for having overcome adversity -- the SAT and ACT can help create diverse classes of highly talented students. Restoring the tests might also help address a different frustration that many Americans have with the admissions process at elite universities: that it has become too opaque and unconnected to merit.Given the data, why haven't colleges reinstated their test requirements?For one thing, standardized tests are easy to dislike. They create stress for millions of teenagers. The tests seem to reduce the talent and potential of a human being to a single number. The SAT's original name, the Scholastic Aptitude Test, implied a rigor that even its current defenders would not claim. COVID, in short, created an opportunity for American society to cast off a tradition that few people enjoyed.But another part of the explanation involves politics. Standardized tests have become especially unpopular among political progressives, and university campuses are dominated by progressives.Many consider the tests to be unfair because there are score gaps by race and class. Average scores for modest-income, Black and Hispanic students are lower than those for white, Asian and upper-income students. The tests' critics worry that reinstating test requirements will reduce diversity. The Supreme Court's affirmative action decision has heightened these concerns.If selective colleges made admissions decisions based solely on test scores, racial and economic diversity would indeed plummet. Yet almost nobody in higher education favors using tests as the main factor for admissions. The question instead is whether the scores should be one of the criteria used to identify qualified students from every demographic group.The SAT's history offers some complex perspective. As the test's critics sometimes point out, one designer of the original standardized tests in the early 20th century, Carl Brigham, also wrote a book promoting racist theories of intelligence (which he later disavowed). But a larger rationale for tests was connected to an expansion of opportunity. Administrators at Harvard, who pushed for the creation of the tests, saw them as a way to identify talented students from any background. The administrators believed that these students would go on to strengthen the country's elite institutions, which were dominated by a narrow group of white Protestants, as Nicholas Lemann explained in "The Big Test," his history of the SAT.Today, perhaps the strongest argument in favour of the tests is that other parts of the admissions process have even larger racial and economic biases. Affluent students can participate in expensive activities, like music lessons and travel sports teams, that strengthen their applications. These same students often receive extensive editing on their essays from their well-educated parents. Many affluent students attend private schools where counsellors polish each student's application.The tests are not entirely objective, of course. Well-off students can pay for test prep classes and can pay to take the tests multiple times. Yet the evidence suggests that these advantages cause a very small part of the gaps.Consider that other measures of learning -- like the NAEP, a test that elementary and middle school students take nationwide -- show similarly large racial and economic gaps. The federal government describes the NAEP as "the nation's report card," while education researchers consider it a rigorous measure of K-12 learning. And even though students do not take NAEP test prep classes, its demographic gaps look remarkably similar to those of the ACT and SAT.This similarity "is another piece of evidence that the SAT is picking up fundamentals," said Raj Chetty, a Harvard economics professor who conducted the recent Ivy Plus study with Friedman and David Deming. "It strengthens the argument that the disparities in SAT scores are a symptom, not a cause, of inequality in the U.S.," Chetty said.To put it another way, the existence of racial and economic gaps in SAT and ACT scores doesn't prove that the tests are biased. After all, most measures of life in America -- on income, life expectancy, homeownership and more -- show gaps. No wonder: Our society suffers from huge inequities. The problem isn't generally with the statistics, however. The relatively high Black poverty rate is not a sign that the statistic is biased. Nor would scrapping the statistic alleviate poverty.The data documenting the predictive power of standardized tests is extensive and growing. In the study of Ivy Plus colleges, Chetty, Deming and Friedman looked at several measures of college success, such as whether students did well enough to earn admission to a top graduate school or be hired by a desirable company. Standardized test scores were a good predictor. High school grades were much less so.Last week, three scholars -- Bruce Sacerdote and Michele Tine of Dartmouth, along with Friedman -- released additional research about some unnamed Ivy Plus colleges. It showed only a modest relationship between high school grades and college grades, partly because so many high school students now receive A's. The relationship between test scores and college grades, by contrast, was strong. Students who did not submit a test score tended to struggle as much as those who had lower scores.Some people have worried that SAT scores are merely a proxy for income or race, Sacerdote noted, but the data should alleviate this concern. Within every racial group, students with higher scores do better in college. The same is true among poor students and among richer students.Amid all the subjectivity in the admissions process, the SAT and ACT -- even with their flaws -- offer meaningful information about an applicant's readiness to do high-level academic work. The tests create a fixed benchmark that can be more reliable than high school grades, teacher recommendations or extracurricular activities. "The SAT just tells you a lot about how well prepared students are for college," Sacerdote said.When I have asked university administrators whether they were aware of the research showing the value of test scores, they have generally said they were. But several told me, not for quotation, that they feared the political reaction on their campuses and in the media if they reinstated tests. "It's not politically correct," Charles Deacon, the longtime admissions dean at Georgetown University, which does require test scores, has told journalist Jeffrey Selingo.In 2020, the University of California system went further than most colleges and announced -- despite its own data showing the predictive value of tests -- that it would no longer accept test scores even from applicants who wanted to submit them. In recent months, I made multiple requests to discuss the policy with university officials. They replied with an emailed statement saying that "U.C. remains committed to maintaining a fair admissions process that reviews every applicant in a comprehensive manner and endeavors to combat systemic inequities." University spokespeople declined to discuss the policy by telephone or to schedule an interview with an administrator.It remains unclear whether other colleges will revisit their test-optional policies given the new data. As is, many teenagers say they are confused. They are uncertain about whether to take the tests and what scores are high enough to submit.MIT has become a case study in how to require standardized tests while prioritizing diversity, according to professors elsewhere who wish their own schools would follow its lead. During the pandemic, MIT suspended its test requirement for two years. But after officials there studied the previous 15 years of admissions records, they found that students who had been accepted despite lower test scores were more likely to struggle or drop out.Schmill, the admissions dean, emphasizes that the scores are not the main factor that the college now uses. Still, he and his colleagues find the scores useful in identifying promising applicants who come from less advantaged high schools and have scores high enough to suggest they would succeed at MIT.Without test scores, Schmill explained, admissions officers were left with two unappealing options. They would have to guess which students were likely to do well at MIT -- and almost certainly guess wrong sometimes, rejecting qualified applicants while admitting weaker ones. Or MIT would need to reject more students from less advantaged high schools and admit more from the private schools and advantaged public schools that have a strong record of producing well-qualified students."Once we brought the test requirement back, we admitted the most diverse class that we ever had in our history," Schmill said. "Having test scores was helpful." In MIT's current first-year class, 15% of students are Black, 16% are Hispanic, 38% are white, and 40% are Asian American. About 20% receive Pell Grants, the federal program for lower-income students. That share is higher than at many other elite schools."When you don't have test scores, the students who suffer most are those with high grades at relatively unknown high schools, the kind that rarely send kids to the Ivy League," said Deming, a Harvard economist. "The SAT is their lifeline."Other colleges that still require the ACT or SAT tend to be somewhat removed from the intensely liberal culture of most elite campuses. Applicants to the United States Military Academy, at West Point, must take one of the tests. So must applicants to top public universities in Florida, Georgia and Tennessee. Gallaudet, a university in Washington, D.C., for people who are deaf or hard of hearing, also requires a test score.The strongest case against the tests comes from educational reformers who want to rethink elite higher education in fundamental ways. To them, the country's top colleges should not be trying to identify the very best high school students; instead, these colleges should use their resources to educate a diverse mix of good students and, in the process, lift social mobility.Comeaux -- a professor of higher education at the University of California, Riverside, and co-chair of the state's review of standardized tests -- favors this approach. He agrees that the SAT and ACT predict later success. But he prefers a stripped-down admissions system in which colleges set minimum requirements, based largely on high school grades, and then admit students by lottery. "Having a lottery," Comeaux said, "would make us radically rethink what it means to gain access and also to learn, rather than accepting the status quo."That's not so different from what many colleges already do. The average acceptance rate nationwide is close to 70%. Even many selective colleges admit more than 25% of applicants, and high school grades can be sufficient for that purpose. "Test scores become relatively more important as the academic level of students increases," Friedman said.The SAT debate really comes down to dozens of elite colleges, like Harvard, MIT, Williams, Carleton, UCLA and the University of Michigan. The people who run these institutions agree that social mobility should be core to their mission, which is why they give applicants credit for having overcome adversity. But the colleges have another mission, as well: excellence.They want to identify and educate the students most likely to excel. These students, in turn, can produce cutting-edge scientific research that will cure diseases and accelerate the world's transition to clean energy. The students can found nonprofit groups and companies that benefit all of society.Administrators at elite colleges have justified their decision to stop requiring test scores by claiming that the tests do not help them identify such promising students -- a claim that is inconsistent with the evidence. The evidence instead suggests that standardized tests can contribute to both excellence and diversity so long as they are used as only one factor in admissions.As it happens, most Americans support using standardized test scores in precisely this way. The Pew Research Center has asked Americans whether colleges should consider standardized tests when making admissions decisions. A large majority of people, across racial groups, support doing so.In today's politically polarized country, however, the notion that standardized tests are worthless or counterproductive has become a tenet of liberalism. It has also become an example of how polarization can cause Americans to adopt positions that are not based on empirical evidence.Conservatives do it on many issues, including the dangers of climate change, the effectiveness of COVID vaccines and the safety of abortion pills. But liberals sometimes try to wish away inconvenient facts, too. In recent years, Americans on the left have been reluctant to acknowledge that extended COVID school closures were a mistake, that policing can reduce crime and that drug legalization can damage public health.There is a common thread to these examples. Intuitively, the progressive position sounds as if it should reduce inequities. But data has suggested that some of these policies may do the opposite, harming vulnerable people.In the case of standardized tests, those people are the lower-income, Black and Hispanic students who would have done well on the ACT or SAT but who never took the test because they didn't have to. Many colleges have effectively tried to protect these students from standardized tests. In the process, the colleges denied some of them an opportunity to change their lives -- and change society -- for the better.
summary:
Research has increasingly shown that standardized test scores contain real information, helping to predict college grades , chances of graduation and post-college success.
The relative advantage of test scores has grown over time, the committee found.
Nor would scrapping the statistic alleviate poverty.The data documenting the predictive power of standardized tests is extensive and growing.
Standardized test scores were a good predictor.
It showed only a modest relationship between high school grades and college grades, partly because so many high school students now receive A's.

title: Beyond Tuition: 10 Scholarships for Living Expenses in Australia
text:
Australia Awards Scholarships:

Destination Australia:

University-specific Accommodation Scholarships:

Emergency Loans and Grants:

Australian Government Research Training Program (RTP) Stipend:

Asia-Pacific Access Scholarships:

Endeavour Leadership Program:

Rotary Peace Fellowships:

Australia Global Alumni:

ACU International Student Scholarship:

Securing scholarships for living expenses is a significant concern for international students studying in Australia. While tuition fees often take the spotlight, covering accommodation, meals, and daily necessities is equally crucial. Here are ten scholarships that go beyond tuition, providing financial support for the various aspects of student life in Australia.Sponsored by the Australian government, Australia Awards Scholarships are a comprehensive support package for students from developing countries.In addition to covering tuition, these scholarships include allowances for living expenses and health insurance, offering a holistic approach to financial support.The Destination Australia scholarship is a government initiative that focuses on supporting students studying in regional Australia. It aims to attract more students to regional areas by offering financial assistance not only for tuition but also for living costs. This scholarship recognizes the varied cost of living across different regions.Many Australian universities understand the challenges of finding affordable and suitable accommodation. To ease this burden, several institutions offer accommodation scholarships. These scholarships help cover the costs associated with living on or near campus, providing students with a stable and supportive living environment.Recognizing that unexpected financial challenges can arise, many universities have emergency financial assistance programs. These programs may offer emergency loans or grants to students facing unforeseen circumstances, helping them navigate temporary financial difficulties.Research students can benefit from the Australian Government Research Training Program stipend. While this program primarily covers tuition fees, it also provides a stipend to support students' general living expenses, allowing them to focus on their research without financial stress.Tailored for students from the Asia-Pacific region, these scholarships aim to foster educational ties between Australia and its neighbouring countries. They cover both tuition and living expenses, enabling students to pursue undergraduate and postgraduate studies in Australia.Administered by the Australian government, the Endeavour Leadership Program supports international students with a focus on merit and leadership. In addition to covering tuition fees, the program provides financial support for living expenses, recognizing the overall financial investment required for a successful educational journey.For those dedicated to peace and conflict resolution, Rotary Peace Fellowships offer an opportunity to pursue a master's degree. These fellowships cover not only tuition but also living expenses, acknowledging the importance of supporting individuals committed to making a positive impact on global peace and understanding.Alumni from Australian institutions may be eligible for financial assistance through the Australia Global Alumni network. This support can include living allowances, helping alumni further their studies or projects in Australia or their home countries.The Australian Catholic University provides international students with scholarships covering tuition fees and offering a stipend for living expenses. This holistic approach reflects the institution's commitment to supporting students throughout their academic journey.While tuition fees are a significant part of the financial equation, these scholarships demonstrate Australia's commitment to supporting international students in all aspects of their lives. Aspiring students are encouraged to explore the specific eligibility criteria and application deadlines for each scholarship to make informed decisions about their educational journey in Australia.
summary:
Australia Awards Scholarships:Destination Australia:University-specific Accommodation Scholarships:Emergency Loans and Grants:Australian Government Research Training Program (RTP) Stipend:Asia-Pacific Access Scholarships:Endeavour Leadership Program:Rotary Peace Fellowships:Australia Global Alumni:ACU International Student Scholarship:Securing scholarships for living expenses is a significant concern for international students studying in Australia.
Here are ten scholarships that go beyond tuition, providing financial support for the various aspects of student life in Australia.Sponsored by the Australian government, Australia Awards Scholarships are a comprehensive support package for students from developing countries.In addition to covering tuition, these scholarships include allowances for living expenses and health insurance, offering a holistic approach to financial support.The Destination Australia scholarship is a government initiative that focuses on supporting students studying in regional Australia.
It aims to attract more students to regional areas by offering financial assistance not only for tuition but also for living costs.
They cover both tuition and living expenses, enabling students to pursue undergraduate and postgraduate studies in Australia.Administered by the Australian government, the Endeavour Leadership Program supports international students with a focus on merit and leadership.
This support can include living allowances, helping alumni further their studies or projects in Australia or their home countries.The Australian Catholic University provides international students with scholarships covering tuition fees and offering a stipend for living expenses.

title: 5 Tips and Tricks to Crack IELTS in First Attempt
text:
Understand the Test Format

Work on Time Management Skills

Enhance Your English Language Skills

Regularly Practice with Sample Tests

Refine Your Speaking Abilities

The International English Language Testing System (IELTS) holds the distinction of being the most widely accepted English language proficiency examination globally, for migration, study, and work. It is recognised by more than 11,500 organisations in over 140 countries.The IELTS exam is designed to evaluate how well people who don't speak English as their first language can use the language.It's for those who plan to study or work in an English-speaking place. The test covers listening, reading, writing, and speaking skills. It aims to be impartial and dependable, with results remaining valid for two years.Cracking the IELTS in your first attempt requires a combination of language skills, preparation strategies, and test-taking techniques.Here are five tips and tricks to help you succeed in IELTS exam:Firstly, understand the layout of the IELTS exam. It consists of four parts: Listening, Reading, Writing, and Speaking. Be familiar with the structure, question types, and time limits for each section. Knowing these details will help you effectively manage your time during the exam.Effective time management is essential in all sections of the IELTS exam. Practice answering questions within the specified time frames during your preparation. Pay special attention to wisely distributing your time in the Reading and Writing sections. For instance, in the Writing section, invest enough time in planning before you begin writing to ensure a well-organized response.The IELTS exam evaluates your proficiency in the English language. Work on improving your reading, writing, listening, and speaking abilities. Read diverse materials in English, practice writing essays and reports, listen to English podcasts or watch movies to enhance your listening skills, and engage in conversations to improve your speaking. Immersing yourself in the language will naturally elevate your proficiency.Consistent practice is crucial for success in the IELTS exam. Utilize official IELTS practice materials and sample tests available online. Practice regularly under exam conditions to replicate the real testing atmosphere. This will make you familiar with question types, boost your confidence, and highlight areas that need improvement.The Speaking section can pose a challenge for some test-takers. Practice speaking English with a partner or participate in language exchange programs. Record yourself responding to common IELTS speaking questions and analyze areas for improvement. Work on pronunciation, fluency, and coherence. Familiarize yourself with typical topics covered in the speaking section.
summary:
The test covers listening, reading, writing, and speaking skills.
It aims to be impartial and dependable, with results remaining valid for two years.Cracking the IELTS in your first attempt requires a combination of language skills, preparation strategies, and test-taking techniques.Here are five tips and tricks to help you succeed in IELTS exam:Firstly, understand the layout of the IELTS exam.
Knowing these details will help you effectively manage your time during the exam.Effective time management is essential in all sections of the IELTS exam.
Utilize official IELTS practice materials and sample tests available online.
Record yourself responding to common IELTS speaking questions and analyze areas for improvement.

title: Want to study in the US with scholarship? Crack GRE with these tips
text: Clearing a globally recognized assessment test is an integral part of a student’s journey to pursue higher education in an overseas university of his/her choice. One of the key exams for pursuing higher education in the US is the Graduate Record Examination (GRE), conducted by ETS. The GRE is the world’s most widely used test for securing admission to leading graduate and professional schools in the world.In India, the number of GRE test-takers has surged impressively, rising from approximately 66,000 in 2020-21 to 1.11 lakhs in 2021-22 – marking a notable 68% increase.With the changes made to the GRE in September 2023, the test has been further revised to make the assessment process more convenient for test takers. The most important change was the reduction in test duration to under two hours from about four hours, which has made it easier for students to test their skills in a reduced duration, making it the shortest assessment for admissions to graduate and professional exams globally.Students also stand to benefit from the Best Score reporting under GRE, which allows them the flexibility to submit their best scores achieved across multiple tests and offers a slight edge with official scores being reported in 8-10 calendar days, a tad faster than the 10-15 calendar days of the old GRE. This allows candidates to plan their abroad application effectively.Being Section level adaptive, with no negative marking and its test scores remaining valid for a period of five years, the GRE offers students an opportunity to enhance their prospects for securing admission in leading overseas universities, across multiple streams, including STEM, MBA, Humanities and Law.More and more students, now, are looking for professional certification of cognitive skills, which are factored in by leading global organizations. GRE offers an advantage to students as it is the only globally recognized test which measures a candidate’s cognitive skills objectively.Here are some valuable tips to help you crack the GRE and enhance your chances of securing a scholarship.• Understand the GRE Format: The GRE consists of three main sections – Verbal Reasoning, Quantitative Reasoning, and Analytical Writing. Understanding the format of each section is crucial. The Verbal and Quantitative sections assess your critical thinking and problem-solving skills, while the Analytical Writing section evaluates your ability to articulate complex ideas.• Create a Study Plan: Develop a comprehensive study plan that covers all sections of the GRE. Allocate specific time slots for each type of question and prioritize your weaknesses. Consistent and focused study sessions are key to mastering the content.• Use Official GRE Materials: ETS, the organization that administers the GRE, provides official study materials that closely resemble the actual test. Utilize these resources to familiarize yourself with the question formats and types. The Official Guide to the GRE and PowerPrep software are valuable tools for practice.• Take Practice Tests: Regularly take full-length practice tests to simulate the actual GRE environment. This not only helps in understanding the time constraints but also identifies areas where improvement is needed. Analyze your performance to refine your study plan.• Improve Time Management: Time management is crucial during the GRE. Practice answering questions within the allotted time for each section. Develop strategies to quickly identify and tackle different question types without compromising accuracy.• Enhance Vocabulary and Mathematical Skills: The Verbal and Quantitative sections heavily rely on a strong vocabulary and solid mathematical skills. Expand your vocabulary by reading extensively, and practice mathematical concepts regularly. Flashcards can be a useful tool for learning and reinforcing new words.• Work on Writing Skills: The Analytical Writing section assesses your ability to articulate complex ideas and present them coherently. Practice writing essays on diverse topics and seek feedback to enhance your writing skills. Focus on constructing clear arguments and supporting them with relevant examples.• Seek Professional Guidance: Consider enrolling in GRE preparation courses or hiring a tutor if you need personalized guidance. Professional assistance can provide valuable insights, strategies, and feedback tailored to your specific needs.• Stay Calm and Confident: On the day of the exam, stay calm and confident. Trust in your preparation and approach each question systematically. Manage your time wisely and avoid getting stuck on challenging questions.• Apply for Scholarships: Once you have a competitive GRE score, explore various scholarship opportunities. Many universities and organizations offer scholarships based on academic merit, and a strong GRE score cansignificantly enhance your eligibility.Cracking the GRE requires dedication, consistent effort, and strategic preparation. By following these tips, you can not only perform well on the exam but also increase your chances of securing a scholarship for your dream education in the United States.
summary:
GRE offers an advantage to students as it is the only globally recognized test which measures a candidate’s cognitive skills objectively.Here are some valuable tips to help you crack the GRE and enhance your chances of securing a scholarship.• Understand the GRE Format: The GRE consists of three main sections – Verbal Reasoning, Quantitative Reasoning, and Analytical Writing.
Consistent and focused study sessions are key to mastering the content.• Use Official GRE Materials: ETS, the organization that administers the GRE, provides official study materials that closely resemble the actual test.
The Official Guide to the GRE and PowerPrep software are valuable tools for practice.• Take Practice Tests: Regularly take full-length practice tests to simulate the actual GRE environment.
Analyze your performance to refine your study plan.• Improve Time Management: Time management is crucial during the GRE.
Practice writing essays on diverse topics and seek feedback to enhance your writing skills.

title: Studying in Canada: 10 Important Things to Know
text:
Here are 10 crucial things to know when considering

studying in Canada

:

1. Visa Procedures

2. Global Recognition

3. Cultural Diversity

4. Cost of Living

5. Work Opportunities

6. Scholarships and Financial Aid

7. Vibrant Student Life

8. Academic Recognition

9. Post-Graduation Work Permits

10. Pathway to Permanent Residency

Disclaimer: The information provided is intended for general guidance and informational purposes only. It is not a substitute for professional advice. The application processes, requirements, and policies may change, and it is crucial to verify information through official channels. Users are encouraged to consult relevant authorities, institutions, or legal professionals to obtain the most accurate and up-to-date details.

Embarking on a study journey in Canada is an exciting venture, offering a unique blend of education and cultural experiences. From vibrant cities to world-renowned universities, discover crucial aspects that will shape your Canadian education experience. Gain insights into essential considerations, visa processes, academic nuances, and cultural tips that will enhance your educational pursuit in this diverse and welcoming country.Canada stands as a beacon for international students seeking quality education in a diverse and welcoming environment.Navigating the educational landscape in this vast and beautiful country can be a transformative experience, but being well-prepared is the key to a successful academic journey.Understanding the visa application process is paramount. Ensure you meet all requirements and submit your application well in advance to avoid any delays. The visa procedure for Canada involves obtaining acceptance from a Designated Learning Institution (DLI) and receiving a Letter of Acceptance (LOA). Applicants then create a MyCIC account, complete the online application, and pay the required fee. Necessary documents, including the LOA and proof of funds, are submitted, followed by scheduling a biometrics appointment and, if required, a medical examination.After submitting the application, applicants monitor the status online and, upon approval, receive the study permit to prepare for their journey to Canada. Staying informed through the official Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) website is essential throughout the process.Canadian universities are renowned for their academic excellence and global recognition. Many institutions rank among the top universities in the world, providing students with a high-quality education that opens doors to promising career opportunities. Canada boasts world-class universities and colleges. Research and choose institutions that align with your academic goals and offer programs tailored to your interests.Canada is celebrated for its multiculturalism. It is a multilingual and multicultural country, with English and French as the official languages. This diverse environment provides students with a rich cultural experience and the opportunity to learn new languages, enhancing their employability and global citizenship. Embrace the diversity, learn about different cultures, and be open to new experiences.While the cost of living in Canada can vary by city, it's essential to budget for accommodation, transportation, food, and other living expenses. Be financially prepared for a comfortable stay. Understand the healthcare system and ensure you have the necessary insurance coverage. Many provinces require international students to have health insurance.Canada allows international students to work while studying, providing them with the opportunity to gain valuable practical experience and earn income to support their educational expenses. This work-study balance contributes to a well-rounded learning experience. Explore part-time work options for international students. Canada's student-friendly work policies can help you gain valuable experience while studying.Numerous scholarships and financial aid options are available for international students in Canada. These opportunities can help offset tuition costs and make studying in Canada more accessible for students from all backgrounds.Canadian universities and colleges offer a vibrant student life, with a variety of extracurricular activities, clubs, and organizations. Students can engage in sports, cultural events, volunteer work, and leadership opportunities, enriching their overall experience.Canadian degrees are globally recognized. Confirm that your chosen program meets your career objectives and is accredited by relevant accreditation bodies.Canada offers post-graduation work permits (PGWPs) to international students who have completed their studies. PGWPs allow graduates to gain valuable Canadian work experience, making them more competitive in the global job market and increasing their chances of obtaining permanent residency in Canada. Research the post-graduation work permit program and understand the possibilities for staying and working in Canada after completing your studies.Many international students who have studied and worked in Canada find themselves drawn to the country's welcoming atmosphere and opportunities. Canada's immigration system offers various pathways to permanent residency, allowing international students to establish their lives and careers in this vibrant and dynamic country.
summary:
This diverse environment provides students with a rich cultural experience and the opportunity to learn new languages, enhancing their employability and global citizenship.
Many provinces require international students to have health insurance.Canada allows international students to work while studying, providing them with the opportunity to gain valuable practical experience and earn income to support their educational expenses.
Canada's student-friendly work policies can help you gain valuable experience while studying.Numerous scholarships and financial aid options are available for international students in Canada.
PGWPs allow graduates to gain valuable Canadian work experience, making them more competitive in the global job market and increasing their chances of obtaining permanent residency in Canada.
Canada's immigration system offers various pathways to permanent residency, allowing international students to establish their lives and careers in this vibrant and dynamic country.

The Central Board of Secondary Education has released the CBSE Board Exam Date Sheet 2024 on the official website at cbse.gov.in. CBSE Class 10, 12 Exams 2024 will begin on February 15. Class 10 exams will end on March 13 while Class 12 exams will conclude on April 2, 2024. In this article, we will talk about 6 essential topics, shedding light on their significance and providing valuable insights to ensure a robust preparation strategy for the upcoming CBSE 12th Maths exam 2024.In the pursuit of academic excellence, CBSE Class 12 students embarking on the journey of their mathematics examinations are confronted with a diverse and comprehensive syllabus.Navigating through this curriculum demands a strategic focus on certain key topics that not only form the backbone of mathematical understanding but also play an important role in exam performance.CBSE 12th Maths Exam 2024 is scheduled for March 9, 2024. From the intricacies of calculus to the analytical depths of linear programming, the topics shared below in the article constitute the core of the CBSE Class 12 Mathematics curriculum, serving as a compass for students seeking success in their impending examinations.Here are the 6 important topics for CBSE 12th Maths Exam 2024;Differential Calculus: Limits and Continuity, Derivatives, and Applications of Derivatives.Integral Calculus: Integration, Definite Integrals, and Applications of Integrals.Matrices and Determinants: Properties, types of matrices, operations, determinants, and their properties.Relations and Functions: Types of relations, functions, and inverse trigonometric functions.Vectors: Addition, subtraction, scalar and vector multiplication, scalar triple product, and vector triple product.3-Dimensional Geometry: Direction cosines, direction ratios, distance formula, and section formula.Formulation of linear programming problems and their solutions using graphical and algebraic methods.Concepts of probability, conditional probability, multiplication theorem, and Bayes' theorem.Basic Concepts: Formation of differential equations, and solutions of differential equations by various methods.Linear Differential Equations: Order and degree, solutions of linear differential equations with constant coefficients.Students shall note that practicing regularly, solving sample papers, and focusing on understanding the concepts thoroughly is important for success in the CBSE Board 12th Maths Exam 2024.

About UP Pre-Matric Scholarship

: The State Education Department, Uttar Pradesh is scheduled to close down the online application process for the UP Scholarship for Pre-Matric (Class 9 to 10) 2023-24 today, January 02. Students who haven't registered yet must submit the application form today on the official website at scholarship.up.gov.in.As per the schedule, the UP Scholarship 2023-24 registration began on September 15, 2023.The last date for Pre-Matric Scholarship Registration 2023 is January 02. Students must submit a hard copy of the online application form to the educational institute along with the other documents by January 06, 2-24. The application verification process of the students will be carried out on February 20, 2024.Step 1. Visit the official website at scholarship.up.gov.inStep 2. On the homepage, click on the UP Scholarship Registration for Pre-Matric 2023-24Step 3. Register yourself and upload the necessary documentsStep 4. Submit the form and take a printout of the same for future reference- Marksheet/Certificate of the qualifying examination- Income certificate- Caste certificate- Receipt of fee submitted at school- Bank passbook- Current board/university registration number- Domicile certificate- Aadhaar cardThe UP Pre-Matric Scholarship Scheme is a government initiative in Uttar Pradesh to help students from disadvantaged backgrounds in Classes 9 and 10. It offers financial support to students from Scheduled Castes (SC), Scheduled Tribes (ST), Other Backward Classes (OBC), or Economically Weaker Sections (EWS) of Minority communities. To be eligible, the family's annual income must be below Rs. 2.50 lakh for SC/ST/OBC and Rs. 1 lakh for EWS of Minority communities. The scholarship amount varies based on the category and class.

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)

Q. When are the UK Board Class 10 and Class 12 exams scheduled for 2024?

Q. What are the timings for the Class 10 and Class 12 theory exams?

Students who are going to appear in the board examination can check and download the timetable here or from the official website at ubse.uk.gov.in.As per the official schedule, the 10th and 12th-grade exams for the UK Board in 2024 will happen between February 27 and March 16.The Class 10 (Theory) exams will take place from 10:00 AM to 12:00 Noon, and the Class 12 (Theory) exams will be held from 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM.For Class 10 students under UBSE, the exams will start on February 27 with the Hindustani Music paper. The main exam for Class 10, focusing on Hindi, is set for February 28. In the case of Class 12 exams, the first paper, covering Hindi, is scheduled for February 27, 2024.Step 1. For more updates, candidates are advised to keep checking the official website of the Board at ubse.uk.gov.in.The exams for both Class 10 and Class 12 under the UK Board are scheduled to take place between February 27 and March 16, 2024.The Class 10 (Theory) exams will be conducted from 10:00 AM to 12:00 Noon, while the Class 12 (Theory) exams are scheduled from 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM.The practical examinations for both Class 10 and Class 12 under UBSE are set to take place from January 16 to February 15, 2024.

title: CBSE 12th Physics Exam 2024: Important Formulae You Can't Ignore
text:
Check out the list of important formulae from the Class 12th Physics Syllabus

Newton's Laws of Motion:

Work and Energy:

Circular Motion:

Gravitation:

Coulomb's Law:

Electric Field:

Potential Difference:

Capacitance:

Ohm's Law:

Kirchhoff's Laws:

Power:

Magnetic Field due to a Current Element:

Force on a Moving Charge:

Electromagnetic Induction:

Mirror Formula:

Lens Formula:

Young's Double Slit Experiment:

Photoelectric Effect:

Bohr Model:

Einstein's Mass-Energy Equivalence:

The CBSE 12th Physics Exam 2024 is just around the corner, so it's a good idea to brush up on those key formulas to nail the exam. Check out this handy compilation of important formulas from different chapters – don't miss it!F = ma (Force = mass x acceleration)F = -dp/dt (Force is equal to the negative rate of change of momentum)ΣF = 0 (Net force on an object at rest is zero)W = Fs (Work done is equal to force x displacement)KE = 1/2 mv^2 (Kinetic energy is equal to 1/2 mass x velocity^2)PE = mgh (Potential energy is equal to mass x gravitational acceleration x height)v = ωr (Tangential velocity is equal to angular velocity x radius)a = rω^2 (Centripetal acceleration is equal to radius x angular velocity^2)G = Mm/r^2 (Universal gravitational constant formula)g = GM/R^2 (Acceleration due to gravity on Earth's surface)KE = -GmM/r (Escape velocity formula)F = kq₁q₂/r² (Force between two point charges)k = 1/4πε₀ (Coulomb's constant)E = F/q (Electric field is force per unit charge)E= - dV/dr (Electric field is negative gradient of potential)V = W/q (Potential difference is work done per unit charge)V = Ed (Potential difference between two points is electric field x distance)C = Q/V (Capacitance is the ratio of charge stored to potential difference)C = ε₀A/d (Capacitance of parallel plate capacitor)V = IR (Voltage is equal to current x resistance)R = ρl/A (Resistance of a conductor)ΣI in = ΣI out (Current entering a junction is equal to current leaving)ΣV = 0 (Sum of voltages around a closed loop is zero)P = VI (Power is equal to voltage x current)P = I²R (Power dissipated in a resistor)dB = μ₀/4π (I dl x r)/r³ (Magnetic field due to a current element)F = qvB (Force on a moving charge in a magnetic field)e = -NdΦ/dt (Induced emf is equal to negative rate of change of magnetic flux)1/f = 1/p + 1/q (Mirror formula where f is focal length, p is object distance, and q is image distance)1/f = (1/p) + (1/q) (Lens formula)λ = dΔx/L (Formula for calculating the wavelength of light in Young's double slit experiment)KE = hν - φ (Kinetic energy of photoelectron is equal to photon energy minus work function)E = -13.6 eV (Z²/n²) (Bohr's model formula for energy levels of hydrogen atom)E = mc² (Energy is equal to mass x speed of light squared).
summary:
Check out the list of important formulae from the Class 12th Physics SyllabusNewton's Laws of Motion:Work and Energy:Circular Motion:Gravitation:Coulomb's Law:Electric Field:Potential Difference:Capacitance:Ohm's Law:Kirchhoff's Laws:Power:Magnetic Field due to a Current Element:Force on a Moving Charge:Electromagnetic Induction:Mirror Formula:Lens Formula:Young's Double Slit Experiment:Photoelectric Effect:Bohr Model:Einstein's Mass-Energy Equivalence:The CBSE 12th Physics Exam 2024 is just around the corner, so it's a good idea to brush up on those key formulas to nail the exam.
Check out this handy compilation of important formulas from different chapters – don't miss it!F = ma (Force = mass x acceleration)F = -dp/dt (Force is equal to the negative rate of change of momentum)ΣF = 0 (Net force on an object at rest is zero)W = Fs (Work done is equal to force x displacement)KE = 1/2 mv^2 (Kinetic energy is equal to 1/2 mass x velocity^2)PE = mgh (Potential energy is equal to mass x gravitational acceleration x height)v = ωr (Tangential velocity is equal to angular velocity x radius)a = rω^2 (Centripetal acceleration is equal to radius x angular velocity^2)G = Mm/r^2 (Universal gravitational constant formula)g = GM/R^2 (Acceleration due to gravity on Earth's surface)KE = -GmM/r (Escape velocity formula)F = kq₁q₂/r² (Force between two point charges)k = 1/4πε₀ (Coulomb's constant)E = F/q (Electric field is force per unit charge)E= - dV/dr (Electric field is negative gradient of potential)V = W/q (Potential difference is work done per unit charge)V = Ed (Potential difference between two points is electric field x distance)C = Q/V (Capacitance is the ratio of charge stored to potential difference)C = ε₀A/d (Capacitance of parallel plate capacitor)V = IR (Voltage is equal to current x resistance)R = ρl/A (Resistance of a conductor)ΣI in = ΣI out (Current entering a junction is equal to current leaving)ΣV = 0 (Sum of voltages around a closed loop is zero)P = VI (Power is equal to voltage x current)P = I²R (Power dissipated in a resistor)dB = μ₀/4π (I dl x r)/r³ (Magnetic field due to a current element)F = qvB (Force on a moving charge in a magnetic field)e = -NdΦ/dt (Induced emf is equal to negative rate of change of magnetic flux)1/f = 1/p + 1/q (Mirror formula where f is focal length, p is object distance, and q is image distance)1/f = (1/p) + (1/q) (Lens formula)λ = dΔx/L (Formula for calculating the wavelength of light in Young's double slit experiment)KE = hν - φ (Kinetic energy of photoelectron is equal to photon energy minus work function)E = -13.6 eV (Z²/n²) (Bohr's model formula for energy levels of hydrogen atom)E = mc² (Energy is equal to mass x speed of light squared).

title: Odisha CHSE Time Table 2024: Class 12 Board Exam date sheet released at chseodisha.nic.in; Direct link to download timetable here
text:
Odisha 12th Board Exam 2024 Date Sheet

: Step-by-step Guide to Download

FAQs on

Odisha HS Date Sheet 2024

Q. How can I download the 12th Board Exam 2024 Date sheet for Odisha CHSE?

Q. What does the 12th Board Exam 2024 Date sheet for CHSE Odisha include?

Q. What is the duration of the Odisha CHSE 12th Board Exam 2024?

Q. Are there any instructions or guidelines provided along with the release of the date sheet?

The 12th Board Exam 2024 Date sheet from the Council of Higher Secondary Education (CHSE), Odisha, has been officially published. Accessible through the CHSE Odisha's official website at chseodisha.nic.in, the timetable includes Arts, Science, Commerce, and Distance Education (DE) programmes, and caters to Correspondence Course and Vocational Stream students as well.Scheduled to kick off on February 16 and culminate on March 20, 2024, the class 12 board exams are slated to run during a single shift from 10 am to 1 pm.Prior to this, the practical examination phase is set to take place from January 2 to January 12, 2024.In adherence to guidelines, it is strongly recommended that candidates arrive at their examination centres at least 30 minutes prior to the exam's start time, ensuring a prompt seating arrangement. Allocation of answer booklets to candidates will occur 15 minutes before the exam begins, with question papers distributed just 5 minutes beforehand. However, candidates are allowed to start writing their answers from 10 am onwards, in line with the set schedule.In order to access the date sheet, candidates should follow these steps:Step 1: Go to the CHSE Odisha's official website: chseodisha.nic.in.Step 2: Click on the link titled "Odisha 12th Board Exam 2024 Datesheet" located on the homepage.Step 3: A new PDF file will open, displaying the exam dates for candidates to review.Step 4: Download the page and retain a printed copy for future reference.Step 5: For additional information, candidates can visit the official CHSE Odisha website.Alternatively, you can also check the timetable here To download the date sheet, visit the official CHSE Odisha website at chseodisha.nic.in. Look for the Odisha 12th Board Exam 2024 Datesheet link on the homepage and click to access the PDF file. You can also download from the timetable from the direct link provided in the article.The date sheet covers the schedule for Class 12 board exams in Arts, Science, Commerce, as well as Distance Education (DE) programs including Correspondence Course and Vocational Stream.The exams will commence on February 16 and conclude on March 20, 2024, running in a single shift from 10 am to 1 pm.Yes, candidates are advised to arrive at the examination centres at least 30 minutes before the exam starts. Answer booklets will be distributed 15 minutes before the exam, with question papers given out 5 minutes before. Writing starts at 10 am as per the schedule.

The CBSE 12th History syllabus offers an engaging exploration of India's history and more. It goes beyond mere rote memorization of dates and facts; instead, it explores the broader context of events, cultures, and individuals that have significantly influenced our world.Structured into three main sections—Themes in Indian History Part-I, Part-II, and Part-III—the CBSE Class 12 History syllabus allocates 25 marks to each section, covering four themes within.Additionally, there's a component of map work contributing to 5 marks.The Class 12 History syllabus dives into the ancient Indus Valley Civilization, discusses the intricacies of the Mauryan Empire, and appreciates the enduring legacy of peace and tolerance from Ashoka's rule. The syllabus further unfolds to unveil the scientific and artistic achievements of the Gupta period, the architectural marvels of the Delhi Sultanate, and the splendor of the Mughal era.The syllabus goes beyond India's borders, exploring the ideological clash of the Cold War and the interconnectedness of globalization. This global perspective broadens students' horizons, providing insights into India's distinctive role in the larger historical narrative.Class 12 History isn't solely about committing past events to memory; it's about leveraging that knowledge to confront contemporary challenges. The syllabus actively encourages students to apply their historical understanding in problem-solving, making informed decisions, and navigating the complexities of society.

title: CBSE issues guidelines for Class 10, 12 Practical Exams 2024; Check Here
text:
CBSE

Practical Examinations 2024:

The Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) has issued guidelines for the upcoming Practical Examinations, Internal Assessments, and Project Assessments for the academic session 2023-24, scheduled to commence on January 1, 2024.Students and parents should verify that their subjects are accurately reflected in the list of candidates submitted by the schools.Students need to be aware of the syllabus and subjects for which practical examinations are scheduled.Students are reminded to appear for the practical exams according to the provided schedule, as no second chances will be provided by the Board. Students or parents are advised to contact their respective schools for clarification if they encounter any issues or have queries.Schools should complete the syllabus for Practical Examinations on time. Additionally, they must make necessary arrangements, including preparing and stocking laboratories and identifying Internal Examiners well in advance.It is the responsibility of schools to inform all students and parents about the date sheet for Practical Examinations. Schools must cross-verify the List of Candidates (LOC) appearing for the practical exams from the online system to ensure accuracy in subjects and student categories (regular/compartment/improvement).To avoid any last-minute issues, schools should confirm the receipt of a sufficient number of Practical answer books before the actual conduct of practical examinations. The marks awarded in practical exams must align with the correct maximum marks, following the circular of mark bifurcation.Regional Offices are responsible for promptly sharing the guidelines for conducting Practical Examinations with schools upon release by the CBSE. They must ensure that Practical Examinations are completed within the notified schedule, and marks are uploaded on time.External examiners should be appointed in all schools before the commencement of Practical examinations, wherever applicable. Regional Offices are also tasked with ensuring the timely delivery of Practical Answer Books to schools before the commencement of Practical Examinations.All stakeholders, including schools, students, parents, and Regional Offices, are urged to adhere to these guidelines to ensure the smooth and timely conduct of Practical Examinations for the academic session 2023-24.The Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) has scheduled the theory examinations for both Class 10 and Class 12 to take place from February 15 to April 2, 2024. To ensure uniformity, all examinations are set to commence at 10:30 AM (IST).The Class 10th main exams are set to kick off on February 19, 2024, starting with Sanskrit, followed by Hindi on February 21, 2024. English is scheduled for February 26, 2024, and Science on March 2, 2024. On March 4, 2024, Home Science will be conducted, followed by Social Science on March 7, 2024. The last two exams are Mathematics on March 11, 2024, and Information Technology on March 13, 2024.Following the CBSE Class 12th Science Date Sheet 2024, the exams kick off on February 22, 2024, with the English paper, followed by Chemistry on February 27, 2024. Physics is scheduled for March 4, 2024, followed by Mathematics on March 9, 2024. Physical Education is slated for March 12, 2024, and Biology on March 19, 2024. The final exam for Computer Science is scheduled for April 2, 2024.The Arts stream exams commence on February 19, 2024, with the Hindi Elective and Hindi Core papers, followed by English on February 22, 2024, according to the CBSE Class 12th Humanities Date Sheet 2024. March 2024 is dedicated to core humanities courses such as geography, political science, economics, history, and Sanskrit. The sociology assignment deadline is set for April 1, 2024.
summary:
Students or parents are advised to contact their respective schools for clarification if they encounter any issues or have queries.Schools should complete the syllabus for Practical Examinations on time.
The marks awarded in practical exams must align with the correct maximum marks, following the circular of mark bifurcation.Regional Offices are responsible for promptly sharing the guidelines for conducting Practical Examinations with schools upon release by the CBSE.
They must ensure that Practical Examinations are completed within the notified schedule, and marks are uploaded on time.External examiners should be appointed in all schools before the commencement of Practical examinations, wherever applicable.
On March 4, 2024, Home Science will be conducted, followed by Social Science on March 7, 2024.
Physics is scheduled for March 4, 2024, followed by Mathematics on March 9, 2024.

title: IPU combines B.Ed. with graduation for dual degrees
text:
IPU Admission 2024:

FAQs

When will the online application process for IPU entrance exams begin?

What are the dates for the upcoming IPU entrance exams?

How does IPU conduct its entrance exams, and what is the result declaration date?

What academic changes is IPU planning to introduce this year?

Which courses is Vice Chancellor Prof. Mahesh Verma planning to offer, and what is the reason for establishing exam centres beyond Delhi?

Delhi's Guru Gobind Singh Indraprastha University (IPU) is set to implement various academic measures this year. The Vice-Chancellor, Prof. Mahesh Verma, announced the initiation of online applications for entrance exams starting later this month. Additionally, plans are underway to introduce a B.Ed course alongside the existing four-year graduation program.The online application process is scheduled to commence by the end of January.The upcoming entrance exams are scheduled for April 27th to May 12th, with results expected on May 25th. Notably, these exams will continue to be conducted in an offline mode using 'OMR' sheets, as is the practice every year. IPU organizes entrance exams for approximately 100 academic courses ranging from graduation to PhD. The university aims to streamline the counselling process for the benefit of students.IPU is working towards introducing B.Ed courses in conjunction with four-year BA, B.Sc, and B.Com programs, enabling students to pursue dual degrees. However, the approval from the All India Council of Technical Education (AICTE) for this initiative still needs to be submitted.Vice Chancellor Prof. Mahesh Verma shared plans to offer courses in BA Mass Media, BSc Environmental Science, BSc Packaging Technology, and MSc Food Technology. To accommodate students' convenience, examination centres will be established beyond Delhi, in cities or states with higher application volumes. This move is part of the university's commitment to facilitating a broader reach for its entrance examinations .The online application process for IPU entrance exams is scheduled to commence by the end of January.The upcoming IPU entrance exams are scheduled to take place from April 27th to May 12th.IPU conducts its entrance exams offline using 'OMR' sheets, and the results are expected on May 25th.IPU is planning to introduce a B.Ed course alongside the existing four-year graduation program.Prof. Mahesh Verma plans to offer courses in BA Mass Media, BSc Environmental Science, BSc Packaging Technology, and MSc Food Technology. Exam centres beyond Delhi are established for broader accessibility and to accommodate higher application volumes.

The Vice-Chancellor, Prof. Mahesh Verma, announced the initiation of online applications for entrance exams starting later this month.
IPU organizes entrance exams for approximately 100 academic courses ranging from graduation to PhD.

title: Over 13,600 SC, ST, and OBC Students Exit Central Universities, IITs, IIMs in 5 Years: MoE
text:
NEW DELHI

: Over 13,600 reserved category students dropped out from central universities, Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) and Indian Institutes of Management (IIMs) over the last five years, Lok Sabha was informed on Monday. Union Minister of State for Education Subhas Sarkar shared the statistics in a written reply to a query by BSP member in Lok Sabha Ritesh Pandey.In the case of Central Universities (CUs), Sarkar said that as many as 4596 OBC, 2424 SC, and 2622 ST students dropped out in the last five years.In IITs, 2066 OBCs, 1068 SC and 408 ST students dropped out. In IIMs, the figure remained at 163, 188, and 91 for OBC, SC and ST students, respectively."In the higher education sector, students have multiple options and they choose to migrate across institutions and from one course/programme to another in the same institution."The migration/withdrawal, if any, is mainly on account of securing seats by the students in other departments or institutions of their choice or on any personal ground," he said.The minister informed that National Law Universities (NLUs) have been established under the Acts enacted by the respective state legislatures and as such they are the state Universities."No such data on dropout students of NLUs is maintained by the central government," he said.Responding further to the query on what the government is doing to address the issue, Sarkar said that the government has taken various steps like fee reduction, the establishment of more institutes, scholarships, and priority access to national-level scholarships to aid the students with poor financial backgrounds to pursue their education."For the welfare of SC and ST students, schemes like 'waiver of tuition fees in IITs', grant of national scholarships under Central Sector Scheme, scholarships in Institutes etc. are also there," he said.
summary:
NEW DELHI: Over 13,600 reserved category students dropped out from central universities, Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) and Indian Institutes of Management (IIMs) over the last five years, Lok Sabha was informed on Monday.
Union Minister of State for Education Subhas Sarkar shared the statistics in a written reply to a query by BSP member in Lok Sabha Ritesh Pandey.In the case of Central Universities (CUs), Sarkar said that as many as 4596 OBC, 2424 SC, and 2622 ST students dropped out in the last five years.In IITs, 2066 OBCs, 1068 SC and 408 ST students dropped out.
In IIMs, the figure remained at 163, 188, and 91 for OBC, SC and ST students, respectively.
"In the higher education sector, students have multiple options and they choose to migrate across institutions and from one course/programme to another in the same institution.
"For the welfare of SC and ST students, schemes like 'waiver of tuition fees in IITs', grant of national scholarships under Central Sector Scheme, scholarships in Institutes etc.

In the realm of modern healthcare, the fusion of medicine and engineering has become indispensable, and pursuing a B.Tech in Biomedical Engineering stands as a gateway to this interdisciplinary field. Biomedical Engineering integrates principles of engineering with biological and medical sciences, contributing to the design and development of innovative medical technologies.The programme equips students with the skills to address complex healthcare challenges, such as designing medical devices, developing diagnostic tools, and enhancing healthcare infrastructure. Graduates of Biomedical Engineering play a crucial role in advancing medical research, improving patient care, and contributing to the overall enhancement of healthcare systems.The scope of Biomedical Engineering is vast, both in India and abroad. In India, the healthcare industry is witnessing significant growth, driving demand for skilled professionals who can innovate and implement cutting-edge medical technologies. Biomedical engineers find opportunities in hospitals, research institutions, pharmaceutical companies, and medical equipment manufacturing units.Internationally, the field offers global exposure and collaboration with leading research institutions and healthcare organizations. As the world continues to prioritize advancements in medical science and technology, pursuing a B.Tech in Biomedical Engineering opens doors to a dynamic and impactful career on a global scale.Here's a list of 10 leading biomedical engineering colleges in India, fostering innovation, research, and healthcare advancements:• Indian Institute of Technology, Mumbai (IIT Bombay): Renowned for its engineering programmes, IIT Bombay offers a comprehensive Biomedical Engineering curriculum with a focus on research and technological innovation.• All India Institute of Medical Sciences, New Delhi (AIIMS): AIIMS, a prestigious medical institution, provides a unique blend of medical expertise and engineering technology in its Biomedical Engineering programme.• Vellore Institute of Technology, Vellore (VIT): VIT is a leading institute with state-of-the-art facilities, offering a specialized B.Tech programme in Biomedical Engineering.• Manipal Institute of Technology, Manipal (MIT): MIT is known for its holistic approach to education, fostering a creative and research-oriented environment for Biomedical Engineering students.• National Institute of Technology, Rourkela (NIT Rourkela): NIT Rourkela's Biomedical Engineering programme emphasizes hands-on training and collaborative research, preparing students for real-world applications.• Birla Institute of Technology, Mesra (BIT Mesra): BIT Mesra's programme in Biomedical Engineering focuses on innovation and entrepreneurship, encouraging students to contribute to the evolving healthcare landscape.• Sardar Patel Institute of Technology, Mumbai (SPIT): SPIT combines engineering excellence with a focus on healthcare applications, offering a comprehensive Biomedical Engineering curriculum.• SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Chennai (SRMIST): SRMIST provides a dynamic learning environment for Biomedical Engineering students, emphasizing research and development in medical technologies.• Amity University, Noida: Amity's B.Tech in Biomedical Engineering is designed to nurture future leaders in the field, fostering a multidisciplinary approach to healthcare solutions.• Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University, Hyderabad (JNTUH): JNTUH's Biomedical Engineering programme emphasizes practical skills and research, preparing students for diverse roles in the healthcare industry.

In India, engineering remains a highly sought-after profession, consistently attracting a large pool of aspiring candidates. The enduring popularity of engineering is evident in the substantial number of students appearing for entrance exams like the Joint Entrance Examination (JEE) for engineering colleges. In 2023 alone, over 13 lakh candidates participated in JEE, underscoring the unwavering interest in engineering as a career path.Engineering is popular because of a number of reasons, such as high demand, a wide range of career options, social recognition, high salaries, global applicability, potential for innovation, personal fulfilment, and opportunities for lifelong learning.For aspirant students, these elements work together to make engineering a compelling and fulfilling career option.The diversified landscape of engineering disciplines is a compelling factor driving its popularity among Indian students. Among the multitude of sought-after engineering programs, chemical engineering stands out as an enticing option, offering a diverse spectrum of career paths. Chemical engineers play a pivotal role in transforming raw materials into useful products, utilizing their expertise in chemistry and engineering principles to design, develop, and optimize chemical processes. Their contributions impact a wide range of industries, including:and many more, such as Materials engineering, Polymer or even Food engineering.Popular and prominent engineering colleges in Andhra Pradesh, such as which ranked as high as 94 all over India in the NIRF ranking 2023, offers specialised course in chemical engineering. Here we have list 10 engineering colleges in Andhra Pradesh which budding engineers should consider for a career in Chemical engineering.
summary:
Nuclear Engineering: Chemical engineers in this field focus on the design, operation, and safety of nuclear reactors, ensuring the efficient production of nuclear energy while adhering to stringent safety regulations.
Biomedical Engineering: Chemical engineers in this domain apply their knowledge of chemistry and biology to develop innovative medical devices, prosthetics, and biomaterials, contributing to advancements in healthcare.
Petroleum Engineering: Chemical engineers in this field are responsible for exploring, extracting, and processing petroleum resources, ensuring the efficient production and utilization of fossil fuels.
Among the multitude of sought-after engineering programs, chemical engineering stands out as an enticing option, offering a diverse spectrum of career paths.
Here we have list 10 engineering colleges in Andhra Pradesh which budding engineers should consider for a career in Chemical engineering.

The vision and initiation of creating IIMs were attributed to the first Prime Minister of India, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.Founded in 1984, IIM Lucknow, since its inception, has significantly impacted millions of lives, both directly and indirectly, through its faculty, alumni, and support staff.IIM Lucknow is dedicated to shaping its students into value-driven leaders, managers, and global players. The institute actively engages in a diverse range of academic activities, focusing on the creation, dissemination, and application of management knowledge and practices.The prestigious institute concluded its Final Placements 2023 for the Batch of PGP37 and ABM18. The Institute secured 100% placements for the largest batch in the history of its 37-year legacy, securing 632 offers for 556 students and placing students across various roles in Consulting, Finance, General Management, IT and Analytics, Sales and Marketing, Operations and Retail E-Commerce with top recruiters from across the globe.IIM Lucknow successfully achieved the highest-ever average and median CTC of 32.23 LPA and 30 LPA respectively, with the highest domestic and international CTC reaching 1 CPA and 65 LPA respectively.A considerable number of legacy recruiters from both domestic and international markets, alongside new recruiters offering a variety of job profiles, successfully conducted their recruitment processes. Despite the prevailing economic conditions, the placement drive achieved remarkable success due to the unwavering support of recruiters and placement teams. This marked the best placement yet, with over 200 recruiters participating in the Final Placement Process.Some of the top recruiters of IIM Lucknow Placements 2023 included Barclays, Accenture, BCG, Deloitte, Amazon, Jio, Capgemini, and KPMG, among others.Check out the full report of Final Placements 2021-23 by clicking on the link given here for the reference: Check Full Final Placement Report 2021-23 Here

As students await the results of the Common Admission Test (CAT) 2023, those who dedicated significant effort to the CAT exam are undoubtedly hopeful for a fruitful result, eagerly anticipating admission to top MBA colleges in India. One such institution, IIM Ahmedabad (IIM-A) is a highly regarded management college in India and is renowned globally for its rigorous academic curriculum, distinguished faculty, and illustrious alumni network.However, one aspect that consistently draws attention and reinforces its reputation is the placement process.The IIM Ahmedabad Placements serve as a testament to the institute's commitment to producing industry-ready leaders. Year after year, IIMA has set new benchmarks in the placement arena, attracting top-tier recruiters from various sectors. This article mentions the intricacies of IIM Ahmedabad's placement process, shedding light on the organised planning, diverse opportunities, and remarkable success stories that make it an important aspect of the institute's legacy.IIM-A concluded its summer placement process for the PGP-MBA Class of 2024 of the Post GraduateProgramme (PGP) in Management in November 2022 in hybrid mode with resounding success, witnessing active participation from various programs and leading recruitment agencies.According to the IIM Ahmedabad PGP Final Placement Report 2022, the Consulting sector took the lead as the most desired, providing 204 job opportunities, followed by the BFSI (Banking, Financial Services, and Insurance), FMCG (Fast-Moving Consumer Goods), and Engineering/Technology sectors. Within the various functions, Consulting stood out with 213 offers, accompanied by significant opportunities in Product/Category Management, Finance, Marketing/Sales, and General Management. Key recruiters such as Amazon, Microsoft, and Extramarks played an important role in offering a wide range of positions to the students.In the placement process for 2022 PGP at IIM-A, a total of 382 students received job offers from 190 firms with around 220 different roles. The placement process consisted of two stages, namely the lateral process and the final placements, with 59% of the batch being eligible for lateral placements.The highest CTC offered at IIM Ahmedabad, was Rs 61,48,640, while the international median and mean CTC reached USD 51,05,096 and USD 1,08,405, respectively. In the Management Consulting cohort, Boston Consulting Group secured the top spot as the leading recruiter, offering 22 positions. Following closely were other prominent recruiters like Bain & Company, McKinsey, and Kearney.
